https://metro.co.uk/2021/08/19/extinctio.title: Extinction Rebellion promises two weeks of chaos across London from Monday
https://metro.co.uk/2021/08/19/extinctio.text:
Extinction Rebellion (XR) are promising to return to the streets of London ‘like never before’ during two weeks of demonstrations starting on Monday.
Commuters and locals could see major disruption as the eco group ramp up pressure on the government to take action on the climate crisis.
XR say they have a few surprises in store and branded the City of London a key target – but are remaining vague about the timing and exact whereabouts of their plans, to maximise their impact.
The environmentalists have repeatedly caused chaos in the capital but this time around the Metropolitan Police have pledged to make comprehensive plans to deal with the group, telling Metro.co.uk that it will aim to minimise disruption.
Activists are set to descend on Trafalgar Square on Monday morning, warning that the world is running out of time to avoid environmental meltdown.
Occupations at unspecified locations, themed marches and targeted actions are also being planned, including on the Bank Holiday weekend, with the City expected to take the brunt of the second week of action after ‘crisis talks’ in week one.
But the group said they would not target public transport, after one isolated incident at a previous demonstration which attracted widespread criticism.
Speaking exclusively to Metro.co.uk, XR Bristol’s Verel Rodrigues said: ‘We’re calling on everyone who is worried about what’s going on and unsure what to do about it to join us in our own crisis talks to express their frustration at government inaction.
‘Expect a warm welcome, great speakers, loud music, bright colours, plenty of disruptive direct action and a few surprises.’
In autumn 2019, more than 1,700 arrests were made during XR’s 10-day Autumn Uprising, which brought large parts of central London to a standstill for days.
Two other major ‘rebellions’, in April 2019 and September 2020, were slightly less impactful, though last year’s was hampered by the Covid crisis.
XR media team member Alanna Byrne confirmed that the group is hoping this summer’s event will be bigger than October 2019, with 40% of the unprecedented number of attendees being new recruits.
But she did concede that the pandemic could again impact turnout.
Protester Mr Rodriguez added: ‘We invite everyone to join us in holding an intervention on the City of London, to target the root cause of the climate and ecological crisis – the political economy – until the UK Government agrees to implement our new, immediate demand: that the UK Government stop all new fossil fuel investment now.’
Branded the ‘Impossible Rebellion’, activists are being encouraged to take two weeks off work and step up to make the ‘politically impossible inevitable’.
Organisers have already crowdfunded more than £250,00 ahead of the latest demonstrations – which are notoriously creative – with a further £10,000 raised for expected legal costs, suggesting more arrests are likely.
The fundraising page explains: ‘Thousands have been arrested and charged from past rebellions, and 2021 will see the rebellion return to the streets like never before.’
Last month was confirmed to have been the hottest ever recorded on earth, with climate scientists increasingly alarmed by a recent series of extreme weather events.
Mr Rodrigues added: ‘It’s never been more clear that climate breakdown is happening right now, everywhere we look.
‘It’s too late to wait any longer.
‘We are living in impossible times and an impossible situation demands an impossible response – this is why we’re going back out on the streets in big numbers.’
A landmark report published earlier this month also made dire warnings that the world is headed for climate catastrophe unless governments dramatically cut emissions.
The findings came ahead of November’s crucial COP26 climate summit, when the UK will host global talks in Glasgow – but environmentalists fear any agreement will not be ambitious enough.
XR co-founder Clare Farrell told Metro.co.uk: ‘We are in open rebellion until we see real action.
‘This government is a joke, telling us how to wash our dishes when they should be leading the world towards a mobilisation that saves humanity.’
Urging the public to ‘disobey the system that is killing life on earth’, she said: ‘Our leaders in government and business are intertwined in a growth mad political economy that is killing life on earth; they are incapable of doing the right thing because there is too much profiteering and business as usual thinking.’
Londoners may be concerned that their plans and travel will be impacted by the group, but the Met has moved to reassure them that they will try to keep the city open.
A spokesman for the force told Metro.co.uk that it was aware of the protests and said: ‘A comprehensive policing plan is being developed to ensure that any disruption to communities across London is minimised and to deter any criminality.’
Meanwhile, a new youth group called Green New Deal Rising has been launched in response to the recent climate report.
They are planning to get young people to publicly embarrass politicians in viral videos and and urge them to back the Green New Deal bill, which it expects to be put before Parliament in the autumn.

https://metro.co.uk/2021/08/23/extinctio.title: Extinction Rebellion block London road with giant table as two weeks of protests begin
https://metro.co.uk/2021/08/23/extinctio.text:
Protesters with Extinction Rebellion have blocked roads as they began a fortnight of action in London which they say will cause ‘significant disruption’.
The environmental campaigners plan to continue from August 22 until September 5 in the hope of making headlines and getting people to take the climate crisis seriously.
A giant pink table has been placed in the middle of a busy junction in Covent Garden, painted with the slogan ‘come to the table’ urging people to engage with climate policy.
Activists also staged a party game in the street, saying that global leaders were playing ‘musical chairs’ and ‘passing the buck’ over the environment.
Today, activists blocked Trafalgar Square with a marching band to try and force the Government to divest from fossil fuels.
Cockspur Road was blocked with hundreds of protesters in the road next to Nelson’s Column, with a heavy police presence surrounding them.
Our leaders are playing musical chairs with the #climatecrisis. Stop passing the buck @BorisJohnson & come to the table for #crisistalks. We #DemandTheImpossible pic.twitter.com/mjX8jwZ52g
It comes after an ‘opening ceremony’ was held at the Guildhall yesterday, where three protesters climbed the building, sprayed red paint over the walls and unfurled a banner reading ‘co-liberation freedom together’.
Gail Bradbrook, co-founder of the activist group, opened the ‘Impossible Rebellion’ today with a speech expressing solidarity with nations that are disproportionately affected by climate change.
Demonstrations are scheduled in central locations including St James’ Park, Piccadilly Circus – similar to those carried out in 2019 – but more are due to take place in both north and south London.
The Metropolitan Police said a ‘significant’ operation would be put in place to manage the protests over the busy bank holiday weekend, but acknowledged the activists’ ‘important cause’.
In a tweet today, they said: ‘A group of protesters have blocked the roads around Long Acre junction in #Westminster with a structure. Officers are on scene and specialist teams are being deployed. Road closures are in place.’
They said: ‘We are aware and attending a demonstration along Charing Cross Road in Westminster. Part of the road is currently blocked.’
When XR protesters caused major disruption in London in 2019, more than 1,100 people were arrested.
Major bridges and roads were closed during the action, including Oxford Circus where protesters parked a huge pink boat.
It remains to be seen whether the action two years later will make the same level of impact.
Several celebrities have already backed the cause, with Stephen Fry praising the group in a video shared on Twitter, saying they were attempting to ‘recalibrate, realign, revolutionise politics’ through their ‘mucky’ and ‘disruptive’ demonstrations.
Game of Thrones actor Jerome Flynn attended yesterday evening’s protest at the Guildhall, as part of a crowd of 200 people.
He said: ‘We’ve got used to certain systems that are life destructive, we created them, we’ve become addicted to them, and we know the world is burning as a result.’

https://metro.co.uk/2021/08/26/katie-pri.title: Katie Price ‘heartbroken’ as Harvey prepares for first night at residential college days after ‘assault’
https://metro.co.uk/2021/08/26/katie-pri.text:
Katie Price has faced a difficult week as son Harvey Price will be spending his first night at his new residential college just days after she was allegedly attacked in her home.
The former glamour model, 43, spent time looking at future schools for Harvey, 19, where his complex needs could be looked after in their recent documentary, Katie Price: Harvey and Me, which is nominated for a National Television Award.
The college Harvey will be living at is now a three hour drive away from where Katie lives, which the mum-of-five is said to be finding tough.
A source told The Sun: ‘Katie’s heartbroken but knows that Harvey will have a brilliant time at his new college.
‘He’s going for his first overnight stay this week to get used to things and being away from home.’
The residential college is reportedly costing £350,000, with the fees eligible for government funding, though it is not known if Katie has been approved for financial help with the cost.
Katie and Harvey had spent six months looking for the right college for him, where he would be comfortable and his needs would be looked after.
The teen was born with Prader-Willi syndrome, septo-optic dysplasia and has autism and can find unfamiliar surroundings and loud noises overwhelming.
She previously told the publication: ‘It’s so upsetting to think I won’t see him every day but this is the best thing for Harvey and we have to think positively because I don’t want him to think I’m just getting rid of him.
‘When he’s three hours away it will break my heart because I won’t be able to get there as I’ve got to juggle him with my other kids.’
As well as Harvey, Katie is also mum to Junior, 16, and Princess, 14, with ex-husband Peter Andre, and Jett, eight, and Bunny, seven, with ex Kieran Hayler.
Harvey’s first night at residential college comes in the same week that Katie was allegedly assaulted in the early hours of Monday morning, leaving her with a split eye and a suspected fractured jaw.
Katie was taken to hospital after police were called to the house where she was staying at 1.30am, and a 32-year-old man was arrested on suspicion of assault, theft and coercive and controlling behaviour.
He has since been released on conditional bail until September 20 pending further investigation on all three counts.
Katie’s £50,000 engagement ring from fiancé Carl Woods was also reportedly taken during the incident.
Friends and family members have been seen leaving the house where the alleged assault occurred with bags of Katie’s belongings after she was ‘too upset’ to return there herself.
She had claimed the alleged attack was ‘unprovoked’ and had occurred while she was watching television.

https://metro.co.uk/2021/08/26/buckingha.title: Buckingham Palace fountain dyed red and vandalised by climate protesters
https://metro.co.uk/2021/08/26/buckingha.text:
Climate activists have turned the fountain outside Buckingham Palace red this afternoon as part of protests sweeping the capital.
Several people have been arrested after the Victoria Memorial water feature was ‘vandalised’.
Protesters from Animal Rebellion, a branch of Extinction Rebellion, daubed red paint on the sides while the water was dyed red.
The Met Police said: ‘We are on scene and arrests have been made. The suspects are being taken to custody.’
Animal Rebellion defended the action, saying they wanted to raise awareness of a ‘royal bloodbath’: ‘The Crown Estate is the biggest owner of land in the UK and yet chooses to use this land for animal and agriculture and blood sports which decimate our countryside and kill millions of animals every year.
‘Using crown land to exploit animals and our planet is a royal blood bath and we’re here to say that, the more power you have, the greater responsibility you have to lead the way into a future which is just and sustainable for all life.’
HAPPENING NOW: Animal Rebels have dyed the fountains at Buckingham Palace blood red to symbolise the royal families crimes against animals and our planet. pic.twitter.com/bsjhF3mUcb
It comes after protesters blocked a major road in Westminster this afternoon, sitting in the street outside the energy ministry.
It is the latest in XR’s attempt to disrupt Londoners during two weeks of planned demonstrations aimed at drawing attention to the climate crisis, which they say will cause far more problems for people.
Police said they were ‘working to safely remove these individuals as quickly as possible’.
Last night, Scotland Yard announced that almost 200 people had been arrested since the start of the protests on Sunday.
They included activists who glued themselves to a branch of McDonald’s in Leicester Square as well as people who erected a giant pink table in a junction in Covent Garden.
On the first day of the protests, three activists scaled the Guildhall building and sprayed red paint on the walls, unfurling a banner reading ‘co-liberation freedom together’.
Protesters also gathered in Hyde Park today, where protesters dressed in suits held signs such as ‘Money is our God’ taking aim at what many see as Capitalism’s focus on profit rather than protecting the planet.
XR officially began its Impossible Rebellion protests on Monday when demonstrators blocked roads in central London, including around Trafalgar Square.
They are demanding the Government immediately end investment in fossil fuels that are driving climate change.
The Met said a ‘significant’ operation would be in place for the protests over the bank holiday weekend but also acknowledged the activists’ ‘important cause’.

https://metro.co.uk/2021/08/25/extinctio.title: Extinction Rebellion block Oxford Circus as 40 women form ring round huge table
https://metro.co.uk/2021/08/25/extinctio.text:
Extinction Rebellion (XR) activists are blocking Oxford Circus in the latest protest to disrupt the capital as part of two weeks of action on the climate crisis.
The environmental group said 40 women blocked the central London shopping district at around 2pm on Wednesday, before erecting another giant structure with a banner that read ‘COME TO THE TABLE’.
Hundreds more activists then joined the action, with many gluing themselves to the table.
It comes after the group put up a giant table in Covent Garden on Monday – which was later dismantled – before blocking part of Whitehall on Tuesday.
Police warned that there would be disruption to traffic in the area, but say they are attempting to minimise it.
In a statement on Wednesday – the third day of the protests – XR said that two empty chairs were placed facing each on the table ‘to represent an invitation to all those who identify as female, nonbinary or trans’.
It continued: ‘The crisis is here – come and take your seat at the table and demand the urgent action needed to tackle the climate and ecological emergency.’
In a Twitter statement, the Metropolitan Police said: ‘Officers have intervened when protestors were building a structure at #OxfordCircus. Some individuals have glued themselves to the structure, specialist officers are working to support their removal.
‘There will be some disruption to traffic in the area as roads are currently blocked, which we are working to reduce.’
The protests come with scientists issuing increasingly alarming warnings about the likely impacts of climate change, with an international committee issuing a ‘code red’ to humanity just this month.
Today also saw activists from Money Rebellion, an offshoot of XR, gather at the Department for International Trade and hold a mock awards ceremony where a ‘Charred Earth’ award was given to the department.
Money Rebellion said the ‘ironic award’ was ‘presented to those who are making an outstandingly awful contribution to climate change’.
To get the latest news from the capital visit Metro.co.uk's London news hub.
Other activists gathered at the Brazilian embassy to show solidarity with indigenous people in the Amazon Rainforest, while women assembled in Piccadilly Circus to talk about the environmental crisis.
The demonstrations are set to continue next week, when the activists will focus their efforts on the City of London, in an attempt to highlight the links between ‘big finance, fossil fuels and the fossil of politics that is Westminster’.
At least 10,000 people have gathered at the protests and 118 arrests have been made for a variety of offences during the demonstrations.
On Tuesday evening, Animal Rebellion – another offshoot of XR -said at least 36 people had been arrested after a sit-in protest at a McDonald’s in Leicester Square.
Bel Jacobs, a spokesperson for the group, said: ‘Until we have a just transition to a plant-based food system, our climate will continue to suffer drastically, and billions of animals’ lives will continue to be lost every year.’
The UK hosts the crucial COP26 climate summit in Glasgow this November, with XR and other environmentalists hoping to ramp up the pressure on the international community to take meaningful action.

https://metro.co.uk/2021/08/30/tower-bri.title: Tower Bridge blocked by XR protesters with a caravan and a van
https://metro.co.uk/2021/08/30/tower-bri.text:
Protesters blocked Tower Bridge today as part of two weeks of action by Extinction Rebellion in London.
Photos from the scene show police lined up on the road trying to manage the demonstration.
The bridge was been blocked with a van and caravan, the Metropolitan Police said, but has since reopened.
Video from the scene showed one protester being moved on by police as she told the crowd: ‘I love getting my little escort. Look at my back-up dancers; they’re so cute’.
She shouted to others: ‘Whose future?’ as they responded ‘Our future’.
The Metropolitan Police force said on Twitter: ‘Officers were on scene almost immediately. We are working with @CityPolice to get traffic moving again.
To get the latest news from the capital visit Metro.co.uk's London news hub.
In case any @MailOnline, @Daily_Express or @Telegraph readers are wondering how #ExtinctionRebellion continually give the @metpoliceuk the runaround, hereâs exclusive live footage of Tower Bridge this afternoon. pic.twitter.com/UwNyW6EXqh
âGuess what? XR is nonviolent in every way. Big up to @XRIntSol big up to @xr_unify … you know what, I feel like having a little street party innitâAbsolute scenes on Tower Bridge this afternoon.#ExtinctionRebellion #TellTheTruth pic.twitter.com/R6O2AzHlam
‘Activists are also laying on the junction north of Tower Bridge, this is causing further disruption.’
Extinction Rebellion tweeted: ‘Rebels have taken TOWER BRIDGE, and the junction North of there, Mansell St! Tea party is off to a joyous start, with beautiful pink things, come and join us’.
They described it as ‘another Towering achievement as the world’s most famous bridge is BLOCKED’.
Some 11 activists were arrested during action on Bank Holiday Monday today.
It brings the total number of people arrested since the action began to 367.
Protesters are trying to draw attention to government investment in fossil fuels as part of their fifth wave of mass protests on environmental issues.
Demonstrators were seen at the end of the famous bridge in Southwark wearing aprons emblazoned with Tell The Truth and with teapots with Deniabilitea written on them.
Protesters were seen to be removed by the police prior to the blocking of the bridge with a large police presence on the scene of the occupation.
The protests, dubbed the Impossible Rebellion, have been going on since August 23, and have included the fountain outside Buckingham Palace being dyed red, a ‘die-in’ at the Science Museum, and an attempted ‘sleepover’ at McDonald’s.
About 11 Extinction Rebellion protesters glued or locked themselves to the railings inside the Science Museum yesteday.
Five people put their arms through the railings and glued their hands together so they are not damaging the museum’s property, while six deadlocked their necks against the railings.
Some of them were dressed in lab coats, while others were in clothes with Extinction Rebellion logos.
